bug.short_desc: Audio CD can't be detected

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) Compiler: gcc 4.3 OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources
I am not sure which area is responsible for this but the problem is that the device notification isn't detecting my music CDs (original and I tried several). They aren't showing up in Dolphin or the music players on KDE 4.2 Beta2 either. If I log out and the log in with KDE 3.5 then I can play my music CD so i don't think that it's a distro problem. DVDs are working fine and data CDs are also OK. It's only music CDs that aren't mounting.

Version: (using Devel) Compiler: gcc version 4.1.2 (Gentoo 4.1.2 p1.1) OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources

bug.short_desc: dolphin cannot open url /media/sdd1 on removable usb_disks

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.1.3) Compiler: gcc 4.3.2 OS: Linux Installed from: Mandriva RPMs
Hi,
My difficulty is related to bug 156500
Problem is I don't know how to configure removable disks paths and names, as I would be able to do simply with fstab.
So the bug is : when trying to open the external drives though clicking on the usb_disk icon, Dolphin cannot list the url /media/sdcc1 and display an error
Once mounted fstab shows for a disk : /dev/sdd3 54G 2,3G 52G 5% /media/DATA2
Dolphin can list and show :media/DATA2 in the "Emplacements F9" window but not /media/sdd3
when checking through the mandriva disk controler/editor these usb drives are not mounted anywhare per default.
All this is ok to me but how and where can I fix this problem ? How to tell kde-dolphin where to look for and above all not trying to open /media/sdcc ?
thanks Bruno
Sorry, I just can't understand what you're trying to achieve. Any chance to have (much) more context? For instance which usb_disk icon are you referring to?

Hello,
it's very simple in fact
when I plug in usb devices some icons appear in the task bar or on the desktop
Whether I have them mounted automatically or not, when I click on the icon to open the storage device with dolphin it fails and alerts that media such and such could not be found : URL media:/sdc1 cannot be opened
sdc1 (for example) is the correct disk name though and it's supposed to be dealt with media storage (there is a permanent icon on the desk called "media" (media.desktop)
Now if I click on the icon of the usb-disk that is displayed WITHIN Dolphin in the left panel (sorry my technical english is limited there, en french it's called "emplacement") it opens correctly and the path is /MEDIA/disk_name
I think all that has to do with dealing with media storages, such as usb CD's, DVD's, but I have no idea how to play on the parameters
Thanks Bruno

Oh! I see, it's actually a downstream issue I think. You're seeing a KDE3 popup dialog when you plug your device right? It's actually coming from an old KDE3 component which can be defunct in a KDE4 session depending how the distribution is dealing with the KDE3->KDE4 migration.
Please report that to your distribution, the necessary integration work to not autostart the old KDE3 medianotifier in KDE4 sessions should be done there IMO.
Then closing as downstream.

bug.short_desc: Mounted Removable Devices periodically unmount during inactivity

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.1.3) OS: Linux Installed from: SuSE RPMs
This was originally reported downstream here: https://bugzilla.novell.com/475738
I am running the up-to-date version of openSUSE 11.1 with KDE 4.1.3.
Mounted removable media such as USB sticks, USB hard disks, and DVDs will sometimes get unmounted when it is not in use (in other words, no lock files is on the media).
However, an example when this does not happen is watching video from a file on the removable drives.
Reproducible: Sometimes
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Plug in any removable media (USB stick/hdd) and mount it (using Dolphin/KDE4 Applet). 2.Close any programs that may lock the media. Leaves it for a few minutes. 3.Open dolphin. Now the media icon on the left pane shows that it is unmounted. Actual Results: As in step 3.
Expected Results: The removable media should be left mounted. However, if this is a feature (eg. to save power), at least increase the inactivity time before automatically unmount the media to 15 - 30 minutes.

bug.short_desc: Locale settings and hal options ignored mounting removable devices

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.2.0) OS: Linux Installed from: Slackware Packages
I'm reporting this bug in dolphin's sections, I don't know exactly wich component of kde is involved in removable devices mounting. Also konqueror is affected after a removable device has been mounting through dolphin or devices notifier in the taskbar, and shell-based operations as well after such a mount.
The probem is this: kde mounts devices not listed in /etc/fstab through Hal, but no utf8 or any kind of locale setting is passed to Hal. I've testes this bug with an usb pendrive and a mp3 player, both formatted in fat. After the device has been mounted, there is no way to handle non-latin characters (i.e. accented). This problem does not occur if I mount manually these devices (mount /dev/sda1 /mymountpoint) or if I use Xfce to mount it. I'm on Skackware 12.2.
Steps to reproduce: plug in a removable device (NOT listed in /etc/fstab), then try to create a file or a folder with an accented character: this one will be eliminated. i.e "relatività" becomes "relativit". If the device already contains names with non-latin characters, tehy won't be properly displayed. After mount operation, you can also use a shell and you will have the same problems. But if you mount manually in a shell, all works fine. If you have Xfce, you will see that this problem in not present, too.
I hope this is not a specifc-distribution problem... I don't think it is an Hal's problem, Xfce should use it as well, and it works...

Just tested on KDE 4.2 and it mounts using utf8 as expected. We added code between 4.1 and 4.2 to handle that, so I'm slightly surprised that you reported it against 4.2. :-)
Anyway it works for me.

Maybe it is related to slackware packages, but only kde 4.2 in my system has this problem. I took a look at hal's config files, and they seems ok, with utf8 options, but with Italian characters there are problems... Did you try to type "relatività" as a file name? Did you get the "à" in file name? Are you using an english keyboard with no accented letters? For me, it is still not possible to use accents in file names (please do not confuse apostrophes with accents :-) So it worksforyou, but for me it's still broken... :-(

I've a french keyboard, plenty of accents and weird characters to play with on it. ;-)
Just in case paste the output of "mount" (with no parameters) once your device is mounted to see if it got the right options. But here I definitely can't reproduce any problem.

Ah ok :-)
Well, the output of mount is this:
pendrive mounted with kde: /dev/sda1 on /media/disk type vfat (rw,nosuid,nodev,uhelper=hal,uid=1000,utf8)
pendrive mounted with xfce: /dev/sda1 on /media/disk type vfat (rw,nosuid,nodev,uhelper=hal,shortname=winnt,uid=1000)
Here there is no utf8 listed, but it works... while with kde, wich inserts utf8 in mount options, I cannot use accented letters... Also if I manually mount with no utf8 options, it works... I'm quite confused :-/

I've found the problem.
My locale was it_IT@euro. Now I've set it to it_IT.utf8 and it works fine, finally I can use accented letters. Locale has to be the same used by hal, otherwise there are problems with some characters.
It would be really nice if kde was able to find this conflict of settings: if system locale is not set to utf8, special characters don't work. Could kde check for this and say to the user the solution? It would be really simple and useful...
Maybe I will open a wish.

bug.short_desc: I would like to be able to eject USB stick

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.2.1) OS: Linux Installed from: Fedora RPMs
When I right-click on the name of my USB stick in Dolphin I am given the option to "Safely Remove". However, choosing this does not turn off my USB stick. I have to give the command "eject /dev/sdb1" to do this.
I would like to have the option of removing AND ejecting, as under Windows XP. Then I would be satisfied that the USB stick CAN actually be safely removed.

What would be the rationale for that?
We're actually ejecting devices which require it. We used to always eject but got bug reports from user unhappy to have to re-plug the device if they change their mind.
Marking as WONTFIX for now, I'll change it if I get compelling arguments.

> What would be the rationale for that?
I have a Nokia N95 Smartphone, when connecting it over USB it can act as a USB-storage device. This is a nice feature because I don't need any additional software to transfer files from/to the Phone. However, before disconnecting it, the phone insists on being ejected properly.
Currently I have to issue "eject /dev/sd_" from a root shell manually to archive this.
Maybe it would be possible to mark a device as "ejectable" with a .desktop file in its root foder? Or have two buttons for unmount/eject in solidui?
But it seems like solid doesn't implement ejecting at all for non-optical devices:
# This works: solid-hardware mount '/org/freedesktop/Hal/devices/volume_uuid_4D4D_D15B'
# This works, too: solid-hardware unmount '/org/freedesktop/Hal/devices/volume_uuid_4D4D_D15B'
# This fails: solid-hardware eject '/org/freedesktop/Hal/devices/volume_uuid_4D4D_D15B' (... no interface "OpticalDrive" ... )

Ah, so it's *not* a USB Stick...
Eject is implemented, it's hidden behind the unmount command and done "when needed", that is for devices marked as requiring an eject by HAL. So what's missing is a small bit of configuration for the N95 to mark it as such, just like it's done for the iPod for instance.
You might want to look at the 10-usb-music-players.fdi file shipped with your HAL install. Declare the N95 there and send a patch to the HAL developers to integrate it. Actually I see that a patch which might be relevant got committed in february, so your problem could go away with the next HAL release.

> Ah, so it's *not* a USB Stick...
Well, it is for the original opener of this bug, I was about to file a new one for my N95 Issue at first, but found this bug with the new-bug-wizzard.
> ... that is for devices marked as requiring an eject by HAL.
Ah, so it's a hal configuration issue... I'll see if I can tweak that file to set "storage.requires_eject" for my phone. Thanks a lot for pointing me into the right direction.

FYI: adding a Nokia rule to 10-usb-music-players.fdi sets the storage.requires_eject to true all right (verifyable by "lshal" or "solid-hardware nonportableinfo") Also, when unmounting, solid-hardware seems to try to eject all right. However, my original problem persists, as "/usr/bin/eject" then doesn't have enough permissions on the device node to do its magic. So, solid doesn't seem to be at fault at all here, its more like a distribution issue. (Install eject suid-root? make block-devices world-writable? include the eject-magic into pumount, since that already does the required permission checks? I have no idea...) I reported the bug to gentoo as http://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=270418 in case someone is interested in it.
Thanks for your time!

bug.short_desc: Crash in solid.dll when starting Dolphin or KRunner

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) Compiler: vc90 OS: MS Windows Installed from: Compiled sources
Dolphin crashes when I try to launch it. Windows pinpoints the crash to solid.dll, offset 0x00043235 (EIP: 0x01a73235).
An exactly the same crash happens also when launching KRunner or Gwenview.
Doing a fresh installation and removing the Application Data/.kde directory doesn't help.
I'm using Windows XP SP3.

I can confirm (Windows XP SP3), various crashes (plasma-desktop, gwenview) appear since the update to 4.2.95, while other applications (konqueror, kwrite, juk) start up normally. Some detail: okular works, but crashes (also for solid.dll) when I try to open a file dialogue. So does konqueror, but only if I use the KDE file dialogue - while the native Windows dialogue works. In the taskamanger I can see about ten or a dozen instances of Kwalletmanager open, although I didn't start it and I don't know, which program did.
It looks like the recent update to kdelibs-4.2.95-1 fixed the problem. After installing it I can't see any more crashes with Dolphin, Gwenview or others.
Yes, everything works now, this bug report can be closed.

bug.short_desc: LUKS volumes can't be distinguished

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.2.0) Compiler: gcc 4.3.3 OS: Linux Installed from: Gentoo Packages

If someone has different pass phrases for each volume then mounting becomes a lottery. Created attachment 35651 Patch to fix the crash
After spending ~2 hours on gdb, I found the issue. It seems to be a simple copy/paste mistake. Two instructions were repeated twice and one of them was a "push" instruction, which decreased the stack frame pointer (%rsp) by 8 bytes, without being followed by any "pop" instruction to restore it. So, when the function was about to return, $rsp was smaller by 8 bytes and "retq" would pick garbage as a return address from the stack and crash. I really wonder how it works on your CPU...
So, the attached patch solves the issue for me.

bug.short_desc: "safely remove" usb flash drive to turn device off

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.0) OS: Linux Installed from: SuSE RPMs
I have SanDisk MicroMate card reader (got it with 8GB SDHC SanDisk card). Using KDE 3.5 "safely remove" card reader in switched off (green light turns off), but using KDE 4.3.0 - it's just unmounted. Add please switching device off. It will be much easier to explain to less experienced users that they can take their drive when green light turned off.

That's actually an issue on HAL side IMO.
The card reader is turned off when we issue an "eject" request to it. In 3.5 we were blindly sending this request to any kind of devices which was causing quite a few problem for other users. Now we're using a hint provided by HAL to determine if the device needs such an eject or not. Apparently in the case of your device it is not provided, which can be changed with some fdi file for instance, you probably want to report your issue to the HAL developers then.
IMO that's not something which should be workarounded at our level.

bug.short_desc: luks_crypto device shown two times in places panel

long_desc.thetext:
Hi! I'm not really sure if this is a problem on dolphin or on a lower level in the stack.
This is my current situation: I've a encrypted partition with luks_crypto. The partition is listed in /etc/crypttab and I've configured /etc/PolicyKit/PolicyKit.conf with: <match action="org.freedesktop.hal.storage.crypto-setup-fixed"> <return result="yes"/> </match> in order to allow to the non-root user to mount the partition.
The encrypted partition is not mounted at boot and dolphin places panel correctly displays the encrypted partition with a green shield. Clicking on it makes dolphin request the password: "'Volume (crypto_LUKS)' needs a password to be accessed. Please enter a password"
Entering the password makes dolphin to display the decrypted partition but on the places panel I've two icons now: the encrypted partition (with the "mounted" icon) and after the decrypted one (which is not yet mounted). (*)
Clicking on the decrypted partition on the dolphin places panel makes the partition mount and all works fine, but I still have two entries in the places panel.
In order to umount the partition I've to first umount the decripted one and after I've to umount the encrypted.
IMHO, a better behaviour should be: - display only one partition, not two. - after entering the password the encrypted partition should be hidden and (optionally) the decrypted partition should be automatically mounted. - after umounting the decripted partition the encrypted one should be visible again and it should be umounted too.
I hope to have described the situation in a comprehensible way :-)
Thanks for reading and considering this.
(*): @Peter: at this point there is a side effect on the panel: the "/" (root) partition which is usually hidden it is shown, after mounting the decrypted partition "/" is hidden again. Do you need a separate report?
I've done another test: having the device configured in "/etc/crypttab" is irrilevant. Solid is smart enough to identify the encrypted partition by itself :-)

bug.short_desc: cryptsetup-luks encricted usb sticks are shown but not mounted

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.2) OS: Linux Installed from: Mandriva RPMs
I Installed from scratch a Mandriva 2010 free distribution. It works fine and the KDE 4.3 is much better of the previous one, but....
Inserting a USB stick containing a crypto-luks filesystem, the volume is shown in the pop-up device notifier with the name crypto_LUKS. Clicking on it the luks password is asked for ed Dolphin is started. Instead of opening in to the device directory, Dolphin open in "Documents" and the device is not mounted. The icon of the crypto_LUCKS device also appears in the left panel in Dolphin. Clicking on it the luks password is asked again but nothing works. In the lower part of Dolphin window is shown this error message: "org.freedesktop.Hal.Device.Crypto.SetupError /dev/sdb/ is already setup?"
What I tried:
Mounted by hand using cryptsetup and mount commands. Cryptsetup version is 1.07 Everything works fine
Installed FreeOTFE on windows XP Everything works fine (wow, a linux project that runs only with windows!)
Verified user rights in KpolicyKit (everything was ok) and even forced explicit access right to the user luca (it's me) Nothing changed
Reformatted using FreeOFTE Nothing chaged
Verified that /dev/sdb was there - It was
ls /dev/mapper/ looking for dm-crypt mapping device It was not there
Verified and changed luks password many times Nothing chaged
Changed usb device 3 times Nothing chaged
How to reproduce
- Insert a luks crypted USB storage - Click on the icon - Type the luks password
Expected Behaviour
- Insert a luks crypted USB storage - Click on the icon - Type the luks password

An obvious line is missing in Expected behaviour: the crypted volume is mounted
I made some more tests.
Crypted partitions in the fixed disk are correctly handled and work fine. I made a NTFS-3G crypted partition containing a ext4 volume and dolphin opens it correctly after having asked for the luks password.
A strange behaviour I noticed: If dm_mod is not loaded, a "wrong password" message is always shown, no matter if the password is right or wrong.
Using the usb storage, if dm_mod module is non loaded, is always shown a "wrong password" message. If dm_mod is loaded, a wrong password gives a "wrong password" message, a right password causes a "org.freedesktop.Hal.Device.Crypto.SetupError /dev/sdb/ is already setup?" message
Luca

Some more investigation:
I made a mistake in previous tests:
The dm-crypt mapped device is created /dev/mapper/ but is not mounted in /media /somedisk/. mounting it by the mount command makes it work
So, the problem is only in the last stage: - I insert the crypted USB -> the device is recognized and shown - I click on the icon -> the luks password is asked for - I look in /dev/mapper and i find luks_crypto_xxxx but no /media/disk is created - I mkdir a /media/disk directory and I mount luks_crypt_xxxxx - The device works
So the problem is only in the last stage; may be the missing directory prevents mount from working?

No comments at all from other persons; may be I'm the only one interested in using encrypted usb memories.
I digged some more, searching in my system and googling around in the web. 1) The problem doesn't come from kde software, as the same problem affects Gnome Desktop; I didn't noticed it before because I use only KDE and XFCE and had to install Gnome in my computer to do some tests 2) The problem is probably due to hal <-> cryptsetup interaction layer, maybe in hal scripts 3) Encrypted partitions are correctly handled: the problem comes out only when there is not a partition table, i.e. a whole volume is used for a filesystem, e.g a USB memory (the bug I founded) 4) The same problem is reported when trying to mount an encrypted CD-ROM (CD-ROMS has not partition table) 5) The "/dev/sdb device is already setup?" error message is generated by /usr/lib/hal/scripts/linux/hal-luks-setup-linux" script, when it looks for existence of the cleartext device mapped /dev/mapper/luks_crypto_xxxxxxxxxxx 6) A (bad) workaround, not always appliable, is to partition the USB memory so that it has a partition table, with only one partition
So, you can close the bug as it's not a kde bug. I'll file the bug to hal and cryptsetup developers.
Bye, Luca
Indeed a problem with HAL closing as UPSTREAM.

bug.short_desc: mmx, sse detection fails with Sun Studio

Ok good. So I guess this can be patched downstream in portage to fix the crash for hardened users until KDE 4.4 is released.
(In reply to comment #15) > But I really wonder (and I'm unable to analyze it further because gdb only > handles core dumps correctly on hardened gentoo) why solid crashed in #line 318 > below: "*that" must contain an element, but the memory dump doesn't look like > that: > > $5 = {<QList<QString>> = {{p = {static shared_null = {ref = {_q_value = 3174}, > alloc = 0, begin = 0, end = 0, sharable = 1, array = {0x0}}, > d = 0x17304fe8}, d = 0x17304fe8}}, <No data fields>} > > 313 QBool QtPrivate::QStringList_contains(const QStringList *that, const > QString &str, > 314 Qt::CaseSensitivity cs) > 315 { > 316 for (int i = 0; i < that->size(); ++i) { > 317 const QString & string = that->at(i); > 318 if (string.length() == str.length() && str.compare(string, cs) > == 0) > 319 return QBool(true); > 320 } > 321 return QBool(false); > 322 } > > Having compiled solid now with -Weffc++, I got many warnings about > uninitialized member variables. Just say so if I should attach a log file.
Whats going on is this: without rev 1069849 the overall list of brightness control devices was not equal to zero, but the list of *Screen* brightness control devices was equal to zero. Thus powermanager.cpp:198 was hit which calls controls.keys(Solid::Control::PowerManager::Screen).at(0). This is where that crash happens. On line 317 a reference is made to the item at 0, but there is no item at zero because we limited to keys (which are the hal device names) by values matching Screen... so when line 318 is called you're getting a null reference and a crash.

Application that crashed: amarok Version of the application: 2.2.2 KDE Version: 4.3.4 (KDE 4.3.4) Qt Version: 4.6.0 Operating System: Linux 2.6.32-rc6 x86_64
What I was doing when the application crashed: What happens:
When I plug in a USB device or put a disk into my dvd drive amarok crashes.
Steps to reproduce:
1. Start amarok 2. put a DVD into the dvd drive 3. crash

During startup of my pc I'm having an external USB harddrive attached to the PC. When trying to enter it or some of the content I'm asked to enter my password. When unmounting I'm having to reenter my password.

I've recently been made aware of some (rather awful) patches the Kubuntu hackers added to our code. From the description you made it seems pretty clear to me that it is causing this password dialog to appear (likely kdesu) because somehow you don't have the rights to mount/umount the disk.
As for why you don't have said rights when you boot with the disk already plugged, it's again probably something specific to the distro, and definitely outside of libsolid and lower in the stack (so out of reach for me).

bug.short_desc: Only able to view/modify PC Floppy contents only once

long_desc.thetext:
Version: 1.3 (using KDE 4.3.3) OS: Linux Installed from: openSUSE RPMs
As the floppy disk option is fixed in Dolphin (i guess it should appear/disappear like the CD/DVD icon), you should be able to just click on it to display the file list of the floppy. When you eject the floppy disk, it should allow the insertion of a new disk for viewing.
When Dolphin mounts a diskette by clicking the icon, it creates the folder to mount on it in "/media", a ".hal-mtab" file containing "/dev/fd0 1005 0 auto nosuid,nodev /media/disk" and a ".hal.mtab-lock" file time-stamped for the first mount in "/media" folder.
Unfortunately when you eject the disk manually to insert a different disk, dolphin does not do the "umount" operation, remove the mount folder or remove the ".hal-mtab" and ".hal-mtab-lock" files. At the minimum, Dolphin needs to issue a "umount" and delete the ".hal-mtab-lock" file to allow the successful insertion of a different diskette.
As a work around to successfully use another diskette you have to follow this procedure which is not advisable for newbies:- 1.load konsole 2."su" to root 3. cd to /media 4. type in "umount /dev/fd0" 5. remove ".hal*". 6. If you don't want to see the contents of the previous diskette or want to always use "/media/disk" as the mount point then remove the "/media/disk" folders.
This may not be a Dolphin problem, it may be a library it uses. This bug is related to bug 199578 which seems to be set to "resolved" that has an odd explanation saying that its the way it should work.
Actually nothing we can do on our side, that would be HAL responsibility to catch when you umount by hand. So upstream issue.

bug.short_desc: KDE Daemon needlessly demands decryption password on startup when KDE resides on LUKS-encrypted LVM root

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 47463 Output of 'cat /etc/fstab' and 'lvdisplay' on my system
Version: unspecified (using KDE 4.4.3) OS: Linux
When logging into KDE on an encrypted system, KDED asks for the password to the LUKS volume. But KDE does not need the password to access the volume it resides on.
Reproducible: Didn't try
Steps to Reproduce: -Install Linux and KDE in a LUKS-encrypted LVM set (for instance, using the OpenSUSE installer). -Boot. Enter the LUKS password.
Actual Results: Upon logging in to KDE, a dialog box soon appears:
Password -- KDE Daemon 'Volume (crypto_LUKS) needs' a password to be accessed. Please enter a password.
Expected Results: The underlying disk structure is transparent to KDED.
Current workaround: -"Cancel out" of the password dialog. KDE can access the entire file system as normal. (Perhaps entering the password works too.) -It doesn't seem to be possible to prevent this dialog from appearing by disabling KDE automount as I can do for external drives.

bug.short_desc: Plasma-desktop will not run from command line - errors out when attempting to restart

long_desc.thetext:
Version: unspecified (using Devel) OS: Linux
If I try and restart plasma (kquitapp plasma-desktop && plasma-desktop) I get the following error: <unknown program name>(30469)/ kdemain: !!{} STARTUP TIME 66561443 START (line: 48 )
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: kill & restart plasma (kwuitapp plasma-desktop && plasma-desktop)
Actual Results: errors out and does not start <unknown program name>(30469)/ kdemain: !!{} STARTUP TIME 66561443 START (line: 48 )
Expected Results: plasma restarts
if I restart kde everyting starts fine

there is a hung plasma-desktop process when this happens: kquitapp plasma-desktop isn't actually quitting the app: it starts to quit, but then plasma-desktop gets hung. this is a recent problem somewhere in kdelibs: we're seeing it in other apps as well. (i've experienced it in ksnapshot, gwenview, ..)
"if I restart kde"
this is because the hung plasma-desktop process gets killed on logging out.
as it's a general problem recently introduced somewhere in kdelibs, i'm not interested in tracking this issue here under the plasma component. if i re-assign it to kdelibs component, i doubt it'll get closed in a timely manner due to nothing pinpointing which component is actually to blame and that the issue is only visible in current trunk. i'll take this to k-c-d to see if we can track down the problem there.
p.s. there is no "kde" to restart; you mean Plasma Desktop :)
tracked it down with my first gdb backtrace: it's in the new Solid fstab backend.

bug.short_desc: Extend the ContentType for Bluray disks.

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) Installed from: Compiled sources
In Solid::OpticalDisc, please extend the ContentType enum to support Bluray disks.

I'm definitely for such a change, but I don't have the necessary hardware to actually test that. I could just add the value to the enum, but no backend would make use of it which would be pointless.
Could you provide me the output of "solid-hardware list nonportableinfo" when your drive has such a Bluray disc in your drive? Thanks in advance.

Hi Kevin,
I do not have a bluray drive but the value is needed for the VLC phonon backend where the support for bluray is almost done. Can you just add the value to the enum please?

Well, my point is that I don't want to extend this enum to advertise a feature we don't provide, in that case none of our backends reports bluray video content.
So I'm curious why the phonon-vlc backend would use this enum if libsolid doesn't report such devices anyway.

This is not related to phonon-VLC yet. This is related to the VLC integration in KDE.
So far, VLC has vlc-opendvd.desktop, vlc-openvcd.desktop and vlc-opencda.desktop, but we cannot create a vlc-openbd.desktop for the next major version because the OpticalDisc.availableContent doesn't have a "VideoBD" option.
I hope this is the right way to do it.

Well.... there is a change: Now kded4 does not try to load powerdevil when it starts even if autoload is set to "true" in kdedrc thus it does not crash. However, when i request the service to start through services manager in systemsettings it crashes kded4 :(
So it seems there is still a problem.
I have only 'svn up' in powerdevil dir in kdebase/workspace. Should i sync the whole kdebase or kdelibs?

I have seen similar behaviour on KDE 4.2RC1 (Kubuntu) - Powerdevil is basically non-functional here. It usually doesn't change profiles when I plug/unplug the AC adaptor. The DPMS and screen brightness settings are ignored. The extra scripts I have inserted are also ignored. I have sometimes seen it throw an error saying that there might be a problem connecting to DBus, as if something has crashed.

I've done some more investigating here. There seems to be a problem related specifically to loading Powerdevil at startup and it is especially apparent if I am also running the Battery Monitor plasma applet.
If I set Powerdevil to autostart when I log in, wait a while after login, then load the Battery Monitor, then it responds very quickly to inserting and removing the AC adapter and changes power profiles correctly (DPMS settings are apparently not applied but that may be a different issue).
However if I then log out and back in, so that both Powerdevil and the Battery Monitor are started automatically, the battery monitor responds very slowly to inserting and removing the AC adapter. Trying to change profiles manually will freeze the machine for up to 30 seconds. If I insert and remove the AC adapter rapidly and then try to open the Power Management settings window I get an error window which says:
"The Configuration module can not be started, since there seems to be a problem with PowerDevil Daemon. Read below for more details PowerDevil seems not to be started. Either you have its service turned off, or there is a problem in DBus"
System settings reports that PowerDevil is running. So it would seem there is a problem in DBus and it's something to do with starting the daemon and the battery monitor togther at login.
I've tried this on 2 different machines, and the behaviour is broadly similar but the slower of the 2 machines is much less stable in this regard, I get the DBus error really almost every time on that one.
Ok, i am closing this because it works in newer versions of KDE

Slightly rework the parser to be more careful about what we consider as the result predicate (if the former result is used in a compound predicate it's not the result anymore). It avoid the double freeing.

That's not a duplicate, it's a completely different issue, this one is about 4.2 breaking binary compatibility from 4.1!
kdebluetooth4 in F10 is built against 4.1, the 4.2 update breaks it => Solid is binary-incompatible, which is a blatant violation of the kdelibs ABI policies.

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) Compiler: gcc 4.3 OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources
solid::bluetooth seems to be not working on qt 4.5, for example solid-bluetooth listadapters returns empty list ans so on.
Looks like DBus calls wich expect QDBusReply<QDBusObjectPath> or QDBusReply< QList<QDBusObjectPath> > as a result from QDBusAbstractInterface::call() result in empty paths or lists.
I believe that my Qt was compiled without -DQDBUS_NO_SPECIALTYPES
After changing calls of first one kind into QDBusReply<QString> and second ones to QDBusReply<QStringList> it works much better

above mentioned change to returned types
Sorry, it is all realted to bluez-3.x

bug.short_desc: Bluetooth support in KDE

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources
I'd like to have a bluetooth support in KDE out of the box. I meant i plug the bluetooth adaper and something should notify me that it's plugged in, works, and give me a way to set a mobile or mouse, or other bluetooth devie up. I tested the new Ubuntu today and it has something like that, what i really liked. I know there is kbluetooth4, but it doesn't compile, or doesn't "see" my adapter, or, or... I report that as a wish, but i think it's a big bug in KDE4. Don't want to be rude, but...

If you have specific bugs or problems with kdebluetooth4 or have specific wishes for it, please refile them. But this wish is too generic to be tracked, since the current situation is almost exactly what you want. You can get compiling help from the kbluetooth4 developers or elsewhere, but not from bugzilla.
Next time: We'd also need to know what version you are using. If you are using a development version, then which?
Thanks!

Maybe I said that wrong. All i meant was to integrate kbluetooth4 with KDE. So when i install KDE, i don't need to get any others apps to use bluetooth. It should be there. Don't you think it would be better?

kbluetooth4 is currently in playground, so I would find it unlikely to be on a default disto release yet. We wouldn't have control over them picking it or not.
In general, that kind of hardware interaction is provided by Solid.

bug.short_desc: Profile managent doesn't allow turning off CPU core

long_desc.thetext:
Version: 1.4.0 (using KDE 4.1.2) OS: Linux Installed from: Ubuntu Packages
I want to turn off one CPU core when running on low power. My kernel enables this with /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu1/online.
Powerdevil say that this is not possible on my system. "CPU can be turned off" is red under "System capabilities" and the option "Turn off the following CPU(s)" is deactivated in profile management.
I run Ubunut Intrepid with kernel 2.6.27-7-generic.
This bug belongs more to solid than to Powerdevil, redirecting it
This bug belongs more to solid than to Powerdevil, redirecting it

The problem is that this feature is not accessible to us through the system. We formerly supported this feature when Solid was running on top of powersaved, but it's not shipped anymore unfortunately so Solid runs on top of HAL which doesn't allow this...
It's then an UPSTREAM (HAL) issue, if it supports shutting down cores again I'll happily support this feature there... for now I close it.

bug.short_desc: powerdevil support for hybrid suspend

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources
Hybrid suspend provides the same short resume time as normal STR while protecting against battery drain same as STD does. Tadeoff is slightly longer suspend time which is usually acceptable (you close lid and do not care whether it takes 10 seconds or 2 minutes to complete).
Hybrid suspend is fully supported by HAL and pm-utils so integrating is is mostly the matter of extra selection in GUI.
Can you please give me some more pointers to that? I'm definitely interested in implementing that

From lshal:
org.freedesktop.Hal.Device.SystemPowerManagement.method_names = {'Suspend', 'SuspendHybrid', 'Hibernate', 'Shutdown', 'Reboot', 'SetPowerSave'} (string list) org.freedesktop.Hal.Device.SystemPowerManagement.method_signatures = {'i', 'i', '', '', '', 'b'} (string list)
What it does, is to save image to disk (like Hibernate does) and then suspend. So as long as you have enough power you just resume as usual; if battery is empty, does normal resume from disk.
I'm taking care of this, though I'm changing component since the implementation belongs to solid.

bug.short_desc: LCD brightness reversed on asus laptops

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) Compiler: gcc (Ubuntu 4.3.2-1ubuntu11) 4.3.2 OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources
This issue appeared in Bug 173518 and I'm pasting comment 15 which states what happens:
I also have an ASUS laptop (G50) and have issues with brightness when starting kde. Additional information:
Using the guidance power manager icon tray (comes with kubuntu) to change the brightness, it works fine.
Using the Battery Monitor applet, a weird behaviour happens: when setting the slider to the right, it gets dark. To the left, it gets bright. I suppose its reversed. But before getting dark, it flicks to bright for some miliseconds. And before getting bright, it flicks dark. Its like its setting "dark" in one place, and then "bright" on the other, and this options are colliding.
So, slider to the right means it will flick bright, but sets dark (which is wrong). But if i use the key (Fn+F7) to power off and then power on the LCD, it gets bright. Ie, turning off and on the LCD "corrects" the problem. This makes me believe powerdevil is "storing" LCD brightness correctly in the hardware, but "temporarily setting" it incorrectly, at least in ASUS laptops.
Oh, and its on Kubuntu 8.10 and KDE 4.1.96 (RC 1)

Adding sebas in CC.
@sebas: could you please take a look at what guidance does differently than us there? I really don't see what could cause such a bug...

Renan, can you see what happens when you issue the following commands?
solid-powermanagement brightness set 0 solid-powermanagement brightness set 50 solid-powermanagement brightness set 100
Please also check
solid-powermanagement brightness get
Kevin: The difference between Plasma's power applet and guidance power manager is that guidance doesn't go through solid, but manipulates HAL through DBus directly.

I did some testing. When I say "resetting", I mean I power off the display, and then power on again. When I say "display is at X", it means the apparent real brightness of the display.
1) set 50 - get shows 53 - after resetting, display is at the same brightness (whether it is 50 or 53)
2) set 100 - display is at 0 - get shows 100 - after resetting, display is at 100
3) set 0 - display is between 50 and 100 (about 75) - get shows 0 - after resetting, display is at 0
I also tried other patterns, "get" always shows a number near the "set" and they all seem to display (100 - get). Not resetting does not change anything except that the display stays at (100 - get). Note that something is different on step 3: changing from 100 directly to 0 makes it display 75. I didn't found another inconsistency like this.
Also, changing brightness with the notebook keys works, but Solid is not aware of that: "get" does not change the value, and when the monitor is reset it goes back to Solid's value.

@Sebas: I know guidance doesn't go through solid, my point was that the solid bits involved in Renan's bug use HAL too, and I'm wondering what we do differently there.
@Renan: The very last point you raise in comment #4 is a known issue, we'll be working on it, but that's probably not relevant for this BR (aka it's fine you raised it but don't be surprised if we don't deal with it here). ;-)
This appears to be resolved at least in KDE 4.2.95 (4.3 RC1) with Kubuntu 9.04 and Linux 2.6.29.

bug.short_desc: KDE4 needs central performance center that enables applications to adapt their default-settings

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE Devel) Installed from: Compiled sources OS: Linux
There are many settings that depend on your computer's performance. The user should not have to bother adapting the default settings to the hardware, e.g. for kwin+composite, eye-candy in general (plasma). Further even less obviously related applications will have serious usability-bugs if there is no possibility to adapt default settings.
An example: Dolphin uses a default setting for creating previews that restricts that functionality to files smaller than 1MB. As a result by default no file that is larger than 1MB will be displayed as image-thumbnail when the user clicks on "preview".
The most useful preview concerns pictures, i.e. photos. Today digital-cameras provide at least a resolution of 4 Megapixel or more. This means that the user will not be able to use the preview functionality with its default settings for photos. Which is pretty bad from a usability point of view.
Of course this setting does make sense for old hardware (very old indeed). So it becomes obvious that a lot of default-settings depend on the computer's hardware. In order to avoid these kind of issues there should be a central point that applications can query in order to adjust their settings accordingly.
Minimal implementation: Provide a place where the user can manually set the hardware's performance-level. At least one would not have to modify each and every application on its own.
PERFORMANCE Graphics: low/medium/high CPU: low/medium/high RAM: <512/<1024/>1024MB
Optimal implementation: Check hardware automatically and provide a button to re-check. Rate graphics/(-driver), RAM and CPU and assign a number to each. An overall value would not be enough since some applications might only need a lot of RAM but no graphics-performance.
As a result Dolphin would use e.g. 5MB as default setting for preview on recent hardware but lower the setting automatically on older hardware. Kwin as well as plasma would adjust the effects used, openGL screensavers would be excluded/included etc.
There is already such a possibility, though we need to investigate that further. The best move would be writing in kde-devel mailing list I suppose

I don't think the issue is a NULL m_battery pointer, but a stale m_battery pointer.
The NULL pointer is the private data associated with a deleted Solid::Battery object. If I read this correctly, Solid::Battery maintains a pointer to a Solid::BatteryPrivate object. This gets zeroed when the Solid::Battery object gets torn down.
But there doesn't seem to be any communication mechanism for Solid::Battery to tell PowerDevilDaemon that the Solid object is being destroyed. That leaves PowerDevilDaemon with a stale m_battery pointer.
That's why I plugged in a QPointer. That allows the QObject destructor to zero out m_battery when the Solid::Battery object gets destroyed.

Reopening the bug. Turns out it was not so straightforward as it seemed.

I've seen this crash again. I'm not attaching the traceback because the NULL pointer in the traceback seems to be distracting from the cause of the problem.
I have, however, added debug messages to the Solid::Battery and PowerDevilDaemon constructors and destructors. The output seems to suggest that the problem is that PowerDevilDaemon::m_battery is stale at the time of the crash.
The PowerDevilDaemon constructor searches for the primary battery as an instance of Solid::DeviceInterface::Battery. It saves a pointer to the instance, assuming that the result of the search is immutable.
But the Solid::Battery object is transient. From what I can see, part of the O/S support suspend/resume issues an "rmmod battery" when the system is being put to sleep, and an "modprobe battery" during resume.
When the O/S deregisters the battery, the associated Solid::Battery instance is destroyed. So PowerDevilDaemon::m_battery pointer becomes invalid.
Without a better idea of the design principles behind the app/library architecture, I don't have a suggestion for how to fix this. But seeing the Solid::Battery object destroyed explains why my QPointer change stopped the crashes. And it confirms that QPointer is not sufficient to fix the problem, since that would simply erase the m_battery pointer with on provision to regenerate the pointer on resume.
I hope this helps decide how best to fix this issue.

bug.short_desc: powerdevil does not detect idle time properly

long_desc.thetext:
Version: 1.3.0 (using KDE 4.1.2) OS: Linux Installed from: Gentoo Packages
My installation of PowerDevil is not detecting my system idle time properly. If I specify any action in the "When system is idle for X minutes" setting, PowerDevil will immediately execute that action, and continue executing that action until I specify "do nothing". Even if I'm typing on the keyboard or using the mouse, PowerDevil just totally ignores the event, and it totally disrespects the idle timeout, and just goes into a loop of executing that action.
I'm happy to provide any other system information that might help track this bug down. If it matters, my system is an IBM ThinkPad T43 with Gentoo's tuxonice kernel. Suspend to RAM and the tuxonice suspend to disk both work perfectly well. It's just the idle timeout that's hosed.
I am using powerdevil-1.3.0 which I backported to my Gentoo installation of KDE-4.1.2.

Hello, thanks for reporting. First of all, assure that PowerDevil is using XSync as a backend. If the capabilities page does not spit out any warning, you're fine.
To check this, please load kded4 from console. It will spit out some debugging messages about powerdevil that give information about idle time detection. If you could paste them there, it would be surely useful.

PowerDevil is using XSync as its back end, and reports no problems with the setup. But when I start up kded4, it dumps back:
X Error: XSyncBadCounter 133 Extension: 132 (Uknown extension) Minor opcode: 5 (Unknown request) Resource id: 0x0 X Error: XSyncBadAlarm 134 Extension: 132 (Uknown extension) Minor opcode: 11 (Unknown request) Resource id: 0x0 X Error: XSyncBadCounter 133 Extension: 132 (Uknown extension) Minor opcode: 5 (Unknown request) Resource id: 0x0 X Error: XSyncBadAlarm 134 Extension: 132 (Uknown extension) Minor opcode: 11 (Unknown request) Resource id: 0x0
Also from xdpyinfo -queryExtensions:
SYNC (opcode: 132, base event: 72, base error: 133)
What else do you need from me?

Doing a little bit of digging into XSync and the PowerDevil daemon code, I've figured out more of the cause of the problem. Calling XSyncListSystemCounters on my system lists only one counter: "SERVERTIME". However, it appears from XSyncBasedPoller::setUpPoller() that the PowerDevil daemon expects to find a counter called "IDLETIME", and will eventually choke if it doesn't find it. That causes the minor opcode 5 failure. The missing counter prevents creation of a valid alarm, so deleting an invalid alarm causes the minor opcode 11 error.
It appears that the IDLETIME counter was added in xorg-1.4. I'm still running xorg-1.3, because that's what Gentoo has as its stable default. I could try upgrading, but it would be a good idea to have PowerDevil fall back to the SERVERTIME counter if the IDLETIME counter is not available. And there should definitely be increased checking of proper Counter and Alarm creation within the daemon.

Thanks a lot for your deep analysis, I can do nothing but confirm the bug and thank you a lot for your report. I'll talk with some X people to know more about the SERVERTIME counter, and add a fallback method anyway.
Thanks again, I wish all bug reports could look like this one.
Looks like SERVERTIME is not useful for checking Idle time. Though, in latest SVN I improved poller loading, and your problem should be fixed. Please test and give some feedback.
I am closing this bug, since the issue should have been fixed and now it correctly falls back to the first available poller

The only thing I feel it can be done is to make PowerDevil detect if the user is running another desktop session different than KDE4, and disable it automatically. Though I don't know if this could interfere with some people who want to run it on DEs different from KDE4.

For instance I started Amarok from my command line (within a KDE 3 session) and it caused kded, ksycoca, powerdevil (and probably other stuff as well but those were easier to spot due to the way they flooded my command line or altered my brightness settings (powerdevil)).
What's obviously wrong is that some daemons/services do NOT need to be launched everytime a KDE 4 application is started. kded, ksycoca and some others make sense but if things like powerdevil are automatically started out of a full session then there are probably many others and this is just plain wrong for two main reasons : * some of these may interact in unwanted ways with the running desktop environment (as it happened for me with PowerDevil) * every such daemon/service it is an utter waste of system resources because the launched application does not require it
My use case may not seem relevant but please consider that there are many people that often use a couple of KDE 3 applications from another DE (Amarok and K3B are good examples) and this behavior is likely to remain for their KDE 4 equivalent (and might even increase considering the opinion some long-time KDE 3 users have about KDE 4).

Most of the stuff actually IS needed, like kded (the kde daemon, for things like cookies in konqueror and other services), kdeinit (for launching kde applications), klauncher (for launching kioslaves such as file, http, ftp, etc). ksyscoca is not a daemon, but it is the kde system configuration cache, a rebuild of whose is triggered whenever a .desktop file in the KDE directories is changed.
Each of it has a particular purpouse, and even it looks a waste for single applications, it is a real memory and performance gain when more than one KDE application is running.
Sorry, but there is nothing wrong in KDE's work.

So this could be (apart from PowerDevil bug that I'm fixing right now) a bug in OpenSUSE packages. Let me explain you how powerdevil works.
PowerDevil queries the system for idle time through some polling backends. Currently it supports 3 backends: the first one, and most efficient, is based on a X extension called "XSync", the other 2, a bit less efficient, are based on XScreensaver.
PowerDevil, when compiled, searches for both XSync and XScreensaver, and enables compilation of a backend if the library it is based upon is found. So, if PowerDevil was compiled without XSync or XScreensaver support, you should definitely report this to OpenSUSE guys.
Or maybe you don't have XSync and XScreensaver installed. I don't use OpenSUSE so I really can't tell you more about this, you'd better check this out with OpenSUSE support, they surely can point you to correct packages

The notification gets displayed before the screen is locked. Though Notifications persist for a bunch of seconds, so if you unlock it quickly you probably see it.

You can, if you have a look at settings. You can set a delay for suspension, that lets you cancel the action if you do not want the PC to be suspended. And this is another case where you definitely want a sound notification

This happens with both nvidia drivers 177.82 and 180.22 if I comment out the DPMS code in the daemon, /apparently/ the problem is solved. Is it the driver or X? It seems that we have quite different video cards with the same issue. xorg-server is version 1.3.0.0 if that might help.

The bug is caused by a dbus deadlock in the setProfile call; the powerdevil runner is waiting for the powerdevil daemon while the daemon is waiting for krunner/screensaver.
Sometimes you can even get two deadlocks in a row (~50 secs) when changing profile with the battery applet or the runner because actually they call refreshStatus before setProfile; this actually means that if for some reason you are in a profile which is different from the "default", you'll get two calls to setProfile. *** is this the expected behaviour *** ?
Following a suggestion by Thiago, the patch works by letting powerdevil emit a signal which is received by krunner/screensaver without any deadlock.
-- it's my very first time to write code with dbus and such, so please have a look at the code; it's should be simple to see if I did something really bad--
Besides, this patch should fix also Bug #178642 (have a look at the code :P)
The patch is composed of one file for powerdevil/daemon and another one for krunner/screensaver
J

bug.short_desc: Dell Mini 9 Backlight Flicker

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.1.3) OS: Linux Installed from: SuSE RPMs
I noticed a strange behaviour on my new Dell Mini 9 Netbook. With the xorg-intel Driver (gma945) the display-brightness flickers randomly every few seconds within KDE4 (opensuse 11.1). I backchecked with the vesa driver - nothing, I tried with XFCE and KDE3 and it was ok, so I think it's a bug in powerdevil that causes the errors with the intel-driver.
It could be, though, to verify this, please post the output of kded4 when flickering happens

How do I get the output? I thought kded runs in background while KDE is running? Any debug options?
Happy new year
You can kill kded4 and then start it again. The output will be flushed to your current console then.

Thanks for the general hint, but two things solved the thing for me:
As noticed in the driver bugreport -> http://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=19237
I changed the backlight control from "kernel" to "native" with $ xrandr --output LVDS --set BACKLIGHT_CONTROL native in .xinitrc That worked first, but it was deprecrated with the update to the newer DELL MINI 9 Bios Version A004. I close this bug now and hope it does not happen again, but after 3 days I did not notice any trouble in that direction.
Thanks, please share this with other users who have your notebook :)

bug.short_desc: Fade laptop screen dimming

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using Devel) OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources

For example on my laptop when it dims the screen because of inactivity the sudden change to minumum is very noticeable, and the same when you move the mouse and it restores the maximum value: I think if it faded in and out it would be a lot more "natural" and less distracting.

What do you mean by hog my screen?
Anyways, it could be an extra checkbox that was disabled by default, but I understand if you leave it as invalid.

On my laptop, the brightness fades because when HAL tells the screen to reduce the brightness, it's the screen itself that fades it away. By "hogging" I mean that subsequent calls could waste battery and in general slow down things, so having it fading manually does not seem worth it to me.

Yeah on my laptop there is no support for fading at all. I don't know if it would waste that much battery (just going up slowly or down slowly over a second doesn't seem like much), but I understand if you don't want to support lame laptops like mine :) Unfortunately I seem to be stuck for a while with this one so...
Thanks anyway.

bug.short_desc: battery applet & powerdevil runner call refreshStatus each time a profile is changed

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.2.0) OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled From Sources
I noticed that both the battery applet and the powerdevil runner call the powerdevil daemon method refreshStatus before calling setProfile. The method refreshStatus rreloads the configuration and then (on a laptop only) it sets the profile to the profile which is the default for the current status (AC plugged/unplugged/low battery/etc..); the subsequent call to setProfile then sets the correct profile, but the transition can be noticed if, for instance, it involves a change of brightness.
I believe that the call to refreshStatus is unnecessary as neither the runner nor the applet should change the profile configuration, but it might well be that I am missing something.
I attach here two patches that remove the call, in case it is indeed unnecessary.
J

Version: (using KDE 4.2.4) Compiler: gcc 4.4.0 OS: Linux Installed from: Unspecified Linux
I found some related bugs but I think none is exactly mine...
I have my laptop configured to use powerdevil. I configured 3 energy profiles. When running on AC power I have Performance, when on battery I have powersave and when battery reaches 25% Xtreme Powersave. My performance profile is set to standby the display after 5 minutes and the other 2 profiles are set for 2 minutes. The other display options (suspend and power off) are disabled. When I unplug the AC and reconnect it everything works perfectly and does what it is configured to do. The problem is when I start up my computer, the performance profile is the default (for AC power). If I didn't switch to other power profile, the display doesn't standby after the 5 minutes. If I switch to other profile (the display standby) and then return again to the Performance profile everything works as it should be. Conclusion: the screen just turns off if I switch the power profile. If I do not switch, it doesn't turns off.
If I set the display to standby with xset it works. I'm using archlinux x86_64 with catalyst 9.6. Since I remember I always had that problem.
Thanks!
I have the same problems here with openSUSE 11.1 and the Factory packages for KDE4 (at the moment KDE 4.3 RC2 4.2.96)
So, that is a problem that continues with kde 4.3... It is not a big problem but it's boring!
Still exist in KDE 4.3.1 release 6 openSUSE 11.2 RC2.
Still there in 11.2 Final and KDE 4.3.3. My screen goes only off at the time specified in "systemsettings - display". It ignores the times that are specified in the powerdevil profiles.
Try to delete ~/.kde4 folder. You'll lose all your kde settings. Make a backup first if you want to reverte your changes. I did this some time ago and it solved the problem.

It's enough to delete those two powerdevil related config files at .kde4/share/config
Works ;)

bug.short_desc: Laptop computer suspend at closing lid, when Shut Down order has been already given.

long_desc.thetext:
Version: 4.2.4 (using KDE 4.2.4) OS: Linux Installed from: Debian testing/unstable Packages
My laptop is an Acer aspire 2920Z, when I order KDE to shut down, it usually wastes between 6-15 seconds to close itself. If during this time I close the laptop lid, KDE put computer suspended on RAM in place of continue the shut down process, this is because PowerDevil is configured to suspend to RAM when lid is closed. But I think when the user has already given to KDE the order for shutdown or reboot, PowerDevil should then allow the process to continue and do not suspend to RAM.
This reminds me bug 183273 (but that should be fixed right now) Thanks
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 189456 ***

bug.short_desc: dim display should remember manual adjustment when restoring brightness

long_desc.thetext:
Version: KDE 4.2.95 (KDE 4.3 RC1) (KDEmod) (using Devel) OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled sources
I have my power saving mode set to automatically dim the brightness when idle (extreme powersave as it is called).
Now the default brightness in this profile is quite low and when working in a bright area I need to turn it up a little. I do this via the slider in the powerdevil plasmoid.
The problem I now have is that, when restoring screen brightness after automatic dimming, brightness is restored to the level in the profile and my manual adjustment is lost (I have to make it again each time auto dimming is applied).
This can be worked around by editing the profile but having to do this for each new place I move to seems tedious and also seems to defeat the purpose of having a control in the plasmoid. For this reason I think it is a bug that any manual adjustments to the screen brightness are not simply "remembered" by the auto-dimming code in powerdevil.
Thanks for considering.
Oh... this bug may be related to 186145
Isn't this a dupe of #190862?
Yes... I'd call it a dup of 190862

Merging. Thanks
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 190862 ***

bug.short_desc: External display turned off when laptop lid is closed

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.2.96) OS: Linux Installed from: Ubuntu Packages
With a laptop, many folks are used to connect a mouse and a keyboard as well as an external display and use the laptop like a workstation - hence closing the lid. However, with KDE 4, an external display (here: DVI-connected) will get turned off whenever the lid is closed, which makes this usecase impossible. This was working with KDE 3, and works with other desktops like gnome, too. I checked power management settings and no matter what I set (started out with 'when lid is closed' set to 'do nothing'), the DVI display is always turned off when the lid is closed. Especially since there is an option in the power management settings which says to turn the display off when the lid is closed, but which doesn't show much of a different behavior from the 'do nothing' setting (except that a brief notification sound is played when the lid is closed and setting is 'turn display off'), I'd consider this a bug.
Issue is fixed after upgrading to Karmic!

bug.short_desc: Nepomuk (strigi) suspends repeatedly after power outage

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.2.96) OS: Linux Installed from: Ubuntu Packages
Every time the power goes out, system is unplugged or I hibernate/standby, upon resume, I keep getting notification every few seconds of strigi suspending and then resuming. Persists for about 20-30mins or until restart or logout.
The service simply connects to the appropriate Solid signal. So I think the problem needs to be in there.
No other app or service exhibits any such effect though.
which other app would that be for example?
Not sure, was referring to any other apps that may listen to the same solid signal. I assume you meant that Strigi seems to be getting repeated power status change signals?
Exactly. The problem is that I do not know of any other app using the signal. But it seems we tracked the problem down to PowerDevil. Will try to debug that.
*** Bug 201731 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Sebastian, bug 200991 is another dupe that I commented on. I find the notifications annoying even before a suspend/resume cycle. On my system they show frequently enough anyway. Besides, I mouse over tip already tells you whether strigi is suspended or not, so maybe those two SendEvents should actually be removed?

actually #200991 is not a duplicate. It is a wish to remove the signals. This is actually a bug where the powermanager reports invalid data, resulting in the strigi service being disabled and enabled over and over again. You are probably right that the notifications are not really necessary, at least I do not need them, except for testing maybe. But I introduced them due to users wanting to know what was going on.

(In reply to comment #8) > actually #200991 is not a duplicate. It is a wish to remove the signals. This > is actually a bug where the powermanager reports invalid data, resulting in the > strigi service being disabled and enabled over and over again. You are probably > right that the notifications are not really necessary, at least I do not need > them, except for testing maybe. But I introduced them due to users wanting to > know what was going on.
Right. I see why it's not a duplicate. I'm all for letting the user knowing what is going on, it's just when that information is flooding the user that it becomes annoying. Maybe a "Do not show again" button on the notification bubble would be the way to go?
IMHO the real solution would be to fix the bug. But I don't have the knowledge for that.
I guess this is fixed in 4.3.1 on Kubuntu 'cause it doesn't happen anymore, no more popups (whatsoever) about strigi status which is fine in my opinion.
What kubuntu fixed is removing the code which raises the notification not the cause.
#12 was right. It back, and still pops up regularly, about every 30-45 secs. Kind of distracting. (Kubuntu Karmic Beta, kde 4.3.2)
Finally fixed it thanks to Jacopo De Simoi.
Have an svn revision number handy? I can't find it.
revision 1038603 in the 4.3 branch.
Thanks a bunch. :)

bug.short_desc: Decrease the luminosity of connected screen when idle

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.0) Installed from: Gentoo Packages
Please, Decrease the luminosity of connected screen when computer is idle than more than X min. It usefull for laptop. Thanks.

Version: (using KDE 4.3.1) Installed from: Arch Linux Packages
I might be mistaken but this option already exists. You can (de)activate it and set its duration in the profiles of Power Management.
No, you can disable the screen only after X min of inactivities, no only decrease the luminosity.

Both options exist!
Each profile is divided in 3 parts: Actions, Screen and Processor.
The option to "reduce the luminosity when the system has been inactive for" (rough translation) is present in the "Actions" part of a profile (its icon is a blue flag).

I have only 2 checkbox: - Disable desktop effects, if active - Dim display when ilde for more than ... If it second option, my wish is: - Use the text above: "reduce the luminosity when the system has been inactive for" - Default active for performance mode after 10min - Allow to choice the level of luminosity
Thanks for your clarifications. Now we only need some capable soul to add this feature.

I'm marking as invalid for the following reasons:
- The option is there and works :) - "Dim" is the correct english term for describing progressive brightness lowering - The level of brightness is automatically adjusted based on idle time. If you set the brightness to be dimmed in 20 minutes, you would have your screen starting to dim over from 10 mins of inactivity - I'll add it a default (I thought it already was, anyway)
Hope this clarifies

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.0) Compiler: gcc version 4.3.2 (Gentoo 4.3.2-r3 p1.6, pie-10.1.5) -march=k8-sse3 -O2 -pipe OS: Linux Installed from: Gentoo Packages
Sometimes when I try to restart or halt the system by the option on menu, KDE just logout and goes back to KDM login screen.

- Which option/way do you use to select "Shutdown" or "Reboot" ? The menu, the Plasma desktop right click, the Lock&Logout widget ? Thanks

I always reboot / shutdown by menu (Lancelot). But I have tried some times and I couldn't reproduce this bug. Let me continue trying, if I see this bug again I'll comment.
Thanks.

Now I think I got it.
In my case, if I execute a command to shutdown or restart the system and close the laptop LID before KDE exits, then it just log off.
- What are the actions configured for "closing the LID" on: SystemSettings/Advanced-tab/Power management/Edit profiles ? Thanks
For the profile I'm using (Performance), it is configured to Suspend to RAM when the LID is closed.
I think this has been already fixed, at least I remember a k-c-d discussion.
Yes, I can confirm, it was fixed. I'm using KDE 4.3.3 and I couldn't reproduce this bug anymore. Thanks for the answers!

bug.short_desc: After update to KDE 4.3.0 suspend/hibernate not working from menu

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.0) OS: Linux Installed from: Fedora RPMs
After updating to KDE 4.3.0 I see some curious behaviour when trying to suspend/hibernate from the menu:
With my normal user account (and quite old config files) suspend/hibernate isn't working from inside the menu. After clicking on the buttons nothing happens. There are also no entries in the relevant logs (/var/log/messages, /var/log/secure, /var/log/pm-suspend, ~/.xsession-errors). "solid-powermanagement suspend to_ram" instead is working. After trying around with a clean user account I've found out that there are two ways to make suspend working again:
1. Enable PowerDevil I've disabled PowerDevil because the description in systemsettings described it as a daemon for laptops. After enabling it again suspend/hibernate from menu is working again.
2. remove a custom file in ~/.kde/env There I have a workaround script for my dual head layout which contains only one line (xrandr.sh): xrandr --output DVI-0 --mode 1152x864 --left-of VGA-0
After I remove this script suspend/hibernate is working, although PowerDevil itself isn't running.
I could also reproduce this with a clean user account where I've only copied over ~/.kde/share/config and ~/.kde/env. I've also tried to remove some config files via trial&error to get the one that's also triggering the suspend. But until now I wasn't successfull.
So ATM I could summarize my issues like this (+ means working, - means not working suspend): + "solid-powermanagement suspend to_ram" is working all the time. + With PowerDevil enabled suspend is working all the time. + With PowerDevil disabled and some config files from my old .kde/share/config and without .kde/env/xrandr.sh being present suspend is working - With PowerDevil disabled and some config files from my old .kde/share/config and with .kde/env/xrandr.sh being present suspend isn't working - With PowerDevil disabled on a clean user account suspend isn't working
So this bug may contain two seperate issues:
1. If PowerDevil is disabled the menu items are doing nothing. This should not happen. At least an information dialog should be shown that PowerDevil is needed to do this. Additionally the description in systemsettings should be re-worked so that it doesn't assume to be only needed for laptops.
2. Some old config files from my user account seems to also trigger the suspend, although PowerDevil itself isn't running. I don't know which file and could need some help for debugging this.
Additional notes: - If "powerdevil-daemon" isn't the right place for this bug, please re-assign it. I wasn't sure where to file it and because PowerDevil is at least partly involved I've choosed this component. - I know that this bug is maybe describing seperate issues. But I have to write it down in one bug so that you could get the context. I'll file seperate bugs if you tell me so, of course. - At least the issue with my old config files are hard to reproduce on a clean user account. If you ask me I could try to upload a tarball of them so that you could try it on your own (I have to remove some personal information first).

Thanks for the report and sorry for the delay.
I'm marking the bug as invalid, read further.
Yes, powerdevil is required for suspension. Though you could file a bug against kickoff to let it use solid if powerdevil is not active, which would make somehow sense.
About the config files, you can send them to my mail ( drf at kde dot org ) to preserve your privacy, then I'll tell you to open another bug if needed (or just reopen this one)

bug.short_desc: powerdevil - wrong in computing idle time

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.0) Compiler: gcc 4.3.2-r3 gentoo OS: Linux Installed from: Compiled From Sources
I run powerdevil on my laptop - whose battery died long time ago, so it's always power plugged. I use gentoo so I do a lot of compiling. I also use yakuake (a terminal - which hides its window) to run the command lines for compiling stuff.
The problem: powerdevil suspends my laptop after I start to compile stuff (like kde 4.3.1 ;) ) in the yakuake terminal if I leave the computer. Compilation is far from ended, the computer is obviously NOT IDLE, but somehow powerdevil thinks it is.
I do not know how it determines the idle time, but if it's based on X, this probably happens because of hiding that window (by yakuake).
Still, this seems a powerdevil problem to me.
thanks, Chris
PS: I think cpu load should be considered too.
I forgot one thing: ktorrent is also hidden, but when downloads are running, powerdevil does NOT suspend my laptop. So, it's probably something else than the window being hidden.

(In reply to comment #2) > I forgot one thing: ktorrent is also hidden, but when downloads are running, > powerdevil does NOT suspend my laptop. So, it's probably something else than > the window being hidden.
hmmmm, I am mistaken here, it seems that the laptop is suspended even when ktorrent downloads
window visible or not, with cpu loaded 100% (which I think means 'not idle'), computer gets suspended!!

The problem is that the idle time is based on the user input, and not on other stuff... applications have a way to inhibit suspension (KTorrent hopefully implemented this), and that's what they should do. If this still persists, please poke the KTorrent guys to implement suspension inhibition when downloading.

Hi Dario, thanks for your response.
That's exactly what I was afraid of. And I respectfully disagree :-) What I suggested is idle = 'unused' but BOTH IN TERMS OF USER INPUT AND AND PROCESSOR USAGE. If I leave a running task that consumes 50% of my CPU then my computer is certainly NOT idle, right?
I thought that some apps (like ktorrent maybe) are doing some magic to avoid this behavior, but my assumption was wrong. Forget about ktorrent, all apps are affected by this. Even if an app could do that magic itself, I think it's not their job but powerdevil's.
What means 'idle' for the linux scheduler I'd ask? I think the same answer would apply in this situation.
At least an extra option in powerdevil (to consider cpu load) would be welcome.
thanks Chris

Hi Chris,
the problem (and the reason why it's not implemented in Powerdevil, gnome-power-manager or whatever) is that there is not a way (not one that I know, I'll be happy if you could prove me wrong) to get the CPU load if not polling the system, which is something you definitely don't want to do, especially on a power manager :)
This is also why applications who perform long background tasks or something else should implement inhibition - there's no way to understand what is idle and what not.
Consider the KTorrent case - here it wouldn't help. The CPU won't rise, now you would have to monitor network traffic as well - and this goes on and on.
Unfortunately the only one telling if there's something going on is the application itself performing the task; this is also the reason why the inhibit interface is a freedesktop standard, shared between KDE and GNOME. It's the only way to prevent this kind of behavior.
Hope this clarifies :)

You are right, the problem is more complicated. Ktorrent is actually a good example where even CPU usage is not enough to monitor. A threshold would be necessary not just for CPU usage but for any type of IO.
...but reading /proc once per minute is not so time consuming, so this polling could be harmless, right?
I think I understand your point. But, as a programmer, I like generic solutions. Especially for generic problems like this one. CPU usage or network traffic or any other type of IO, are all parameters of the OS and I still think that an option to monitor these before suspending is essential in a central location (OS itself, or the power manager, or ...) I'm not talking here about one application or another. I'm talking about *any* application.
Why don't the apps monitor the user input by themselves? Why wouldn't a central entity monitor other resources as well?
I still think user input is just one of these parameters. Maybe it's difficult to implement, but I still think that a 'client' solution is not what is needed (inhibiting suspend by the app itself). I'm thinking here about a custom threshold defined ONCE in the system, valid for all the apps. Once that resource usage is greater, suspend is inhibited. Polling once a minute would do. There is no need to ask all the apps to do this. There would be NOTHING special in an application, a central entity can take care of that.
I agree that for special situation, inhibiting suspend by the application itself is required, but this is only a special case, while the common one (in my opinion) is the one above.
Am I wrong, or /proc can tell enough about the running system/processes?
Please, don't get me wrong, I just think this would be a nice thing to have. I'll have to read about this, maybe I can help.
thanks Chris

Yeah, the solution you're proposing though it wouldn't be a panacea, since polling on such a large amount of time has a too wide error margin. What you say are surely interesting things though, which (unfortunately) I don't have time to investigate further at the moment.
Still, if you would like to give some help on that, I'd be more than happy to cooperate and to accept any patches in this regard. It could also be a good idea coming up with a nice proposal and send it to the kde-hardware-devel mailinglist, so that all of the fellows of the Solid stack (which is where you want to implement such a thing) can read and comment. What do you think?
Sounds good, thanks :-)

...but I think this is a low(er)-level issue, maybe a kernel-level one ?
even if you don't use the X server / KDE / gnome / whatever, you could still have this 'feature', so what would be the starting point?
polling so rarely should not be an issue as long as some 'average' statistics are available; e.g: I just found out about the getloadavg() API, maybe others exist too.
thanks, Chris

Explanation:
I usually leave my laptop on while going away for a little while. When I come back I sometimes start by unplugging the power-cord to be able to move the computer to the living room. bug.short_desc: PowerDevil does suspend-to-ram after power adaptor unplugging

long_desc.thetext:
Version: (using KDE 4.3.1) Compiler: gcc (Gentoo 4.4.1 p1.0) 4.4.1 OS: Linux Installed from: Gentoo Packages
When I have my laptop runnning for quite some time (I guess for at least the "When the system is idle for more than ... min" time) and then unplug the power cord, it will be sent to suspend-to-ram.
I guess the problem is that the timer is running all the time - even when a power cord is plugged in. My suggestion is to only start the timer when the power cord is unplugged.

I can confirm this.
The timer needs to run at all times because the profiles can be configured to do different things after the idle time. This is actually very easy to fix: AC adapter events should reset the idle time timer. More generally, I think any profile switch should cause this timer to be reset.
